Here is a reason to write independent tests and even run nightly 
builds with random order tests. Some classes in our code might have 
order dependent methods by mistake. Those methods might behave 
correctly in a normal order, but in other conditions bug will 
surface. 

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Tung Wai Yip <tungwaiyip@y...> wrote:
> I wrote a testCreate to create and verify a record.
> 
> Then testUpdate to update and verify the record created in 
testCreate.
> 
> Finally the testDelete to test delete the record created in 
testCreate.
> 
> The thress test cases comprise of a suite of test for the 
persistence of one
> kind of record. This contradicts with the idea that each test case 
should be
> independent. On the other hand the test cases are easy to write and 
I'm happy
> with the result. I wonder if there is any convincing reason to 
write a complex
> test case just so it can be totally independently from the others.
> 
> Wai Yip Tung
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- javainsel <javainsel@y...> wrote:
> > We want to test the creation, update and deletion of an object 
which 
> > is persisted in database.
> > 
> > What we now do is to have three test methods for this.
> > 
> > In the testCreate method the object is created, checked that he 
is 
> > really created and then it is deleted (we have delete because 
> > unfortunately we don't use Mock Objects).
> > 
> > In the testUpdate method we create the object, update it, test 
the 
> > update result and delete the created object.
> > 
> > In the testDelete method we create the object so that we can test 
> > the deletion of it.
> > 
> > As you see, everything is included in the testUpdate method. We 
> > duplicate much code in the other two test methods.
> > 
> > We write such tests for every domain object so I wonder if we 
should 
> > improve our test class.
> > 
> > Would you write 3 or just 1 test method for that example?
> > 
> > And would you try to convince senior coworkers who know little 
about 
> > JUnit and dislike TDD?
> >
